divs: Sighting DetailsHelloLong time night observer, familiar with night sky and all objects therein.Last night, 729, at my home in Westcliffe Colorado, while stepping outside tojust enjoy the evening, a bright spot caught my attention. It was just belowthe constellation Cassiopeia in the NE and was brighter than Jupiter or Venus attheir brightest. I was surprised as neither should be there at this time andthis was a little bit too north for either. Then it intensified for 1-2 secondsand then faded quickly to almost nothing. Then I observed a low magnitudeobject at that very point and then I noticed it moving south from that spot.I guesstimated that I was observing a satellite passing over head, somethingobserved often every night and for many years. Also, that the brightness mighthave been brilliance from reflecting the sun and then the angle changes,something I had noticed before.But this was different. As it moved south, it accelerated It moved at first,at the speed of a high flying aircraft or a satellite as observed from theground. Then it appeared to be moving, for a few degrees across the sky, thenfaster and faster until it was moving some 4-6 times any observed satellite Ihad ever seen. It stayed visible for about 5 seconds longer then I lost it inthe glow from the moon, which was in the SSE.In all my years I had not seen this phenomenon.If you have any information on this, please share, e-mail or ask for my number.Noel BergeWestcliffe Colorado
Summary: Bright object fades then accelerates away
